image.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: Barron Trump's 'best friend' says Donald asked him 5 times if...
item.description: ​A social media influencer Bo Loudon who claimed to be Barron Trump's best friend posted several never-seen-before photographs from former president Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club resident in Florida and proclaimed that Gen Z stands with 'rightful president' Trump. The photos were probably taken when Trump sat for a livestream with influencer Adin Ross.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Trump took a break from taking a break to put some pants': Harris campaign trolls 'meltdown'
item.description: Donald Trump addressed an hour long press conference yesterday at his home berating Kamala Harris and Tim Walz. But what followed was a statement from the Harris-Walz campaign which trolled Trump and called it a 'very good, very normal' press conference -- sarcastically. "Donald Trump took a break from taking a break to put on some pants and host a press conference public meltdown," the campaign release said including the strikethrough.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Kamala Harris & Tim Walz camouflage hat raises $1 million: Here's how
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Japan's Kishida cancels Asia trip after scientists urge preparations for a possible 'megaquake'
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida canceled a trip to Central Asia to manage the government's response to a potential 'megaquake' off Japan's southern coast. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued its first 'megaquake advisory' following a 7.1 magnitude quake near Kyushu. Officials urged heightened caution for a week and advised local governments to review disaster plans.

item.title: 'But did JD Vance see combat? He was in public affairs': CNN anchor slammed
item.description: "Brianna this is disgusting, and you and your entire network should be ashamed of yourselves. When I got the call to go to Iraq, I went. Tim Walz said he carried a gun in a war. Did he? No. It was a lie," JD Vance posted on X slamming the CNN anchor who questioned whether JD Vance, as a combat correspondent in the army, was even in a combat.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Russia declares emergency in Kursk region as Ukraine launches mega attack
item.description: Russia declared a federal-level emergency in the Kursk region after a substantial incursion from Ukraine, mobilizing reinforcements to counter the attack. This incident followed Ukrainian troops crossing the border, representing Kyiv's largest attack on Russian soil since the war's onset. Concurrently, a Russian missile strike on a Ukrainian shopping mall resulted in multiple casualties.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Russia will be held accountable': Zelenskyy vows retaliation after Russian strike on supermarket kills 10, injures 35
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Listen...': Tim Walz's 'stolen valor' controversy gets Kamala Harris' reaction
item.description: Tim Walz served 24 years in various units and jobs in the Army National Guard. He retired from service in May 2005 when he was up for his congressional bid. In August 2005, the unit that Walz was serving was asked to mobilize and in March 2006, it was deployed to Iraq. There is no evidence that Walz retired from the service to avoid deployment.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Willie Brown says Kamala Harris was a good friend, can't think in negative way
item.description: Donald Trump in his press conference yesterday said he knows Kamala Harris' ex-boyfriend Willie Brown and that they had an emergency experience during a helicopter ride and that Brown told terrible things about Kamala Harris. Now Willie Brown, the former San Francisco mayor, completely denied everything calling whatever Trump said his figment of imagination.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Covid-19 drops to 10th leading cause of death in US as overall mortality declines
item.description: The CDC reported that Covid-19 fell to the 10th leading cause of death in the US in 2023, down from third at the pandemic’s peak. Death rates decreased across all age groups and racial demographics. Heart disease, cancer, and injuries, including gun-related deaths and drug overdoses, emerged as the top causes of death in 2023.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Samantha Murphy murder case delayed over 'unprecedented' amount of evidence against accused
item.description: Patrick Orren Stephenson will remain in custody for another three months due to the large amount of evidence against him in the case of Samantha Murphy's murder. Despite opposition from his lawyer, the court granted an extension. Murphy, a mother of three, was reported missing on February 4 in Mount Clear. Stephenson also faces charges related to a previous crash.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Nevada man charged with hate crime after 'hanging tree' comment at car show
item.description: Three individuals were arrested in Nevada after a confrontation with a Black man collecting signatures, during which a 'hanging tree' was mentioned. Gary Miller, 74, his wife, and daughter face multiple misdemeanor charges. The incident, recorded during a Virginia City car show, led to backlash. Nevada Attorney General Aaron Ford praised the arrests.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Huge California wildfire chews through timber in very hot and dry weather
item.description: California's largest wildfire of the year, the Park Fire, grew rapidly due to hot and dry weather, burning over 660 square miles since July 24. Containment remained at 34%, and authorities focused on curtailing spot fires. A man was arrested for allegedly starting the fire, which destroyed hundreds of structures.

item.title: 'Meghan Markle allegedly screaming after CBS interview': Duchess of Sussex faces fresh controversy over tense TV appearance with Prince Harry
item.description: After their recent interview, Meghan Markle reportedly had a 'meltdown,' being very upset and angry about unexpected questions regarding her suicidal thoughts. Experts noted visible tension between Meghan and Prince Harry, describing the interview as a 'car crash' due to their awkward dynamics and Meghan's frustration with the producers and her husband's responses.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: The world's most dangerous volcanoes: Waiting for the next eruption
item.description: The article investigates the world's most dangerous volcanoes, highlighting their historical eruptions and current threats. Notable mentions include Mount Vesuvius, Mount St. Helens, and Mount Merapi, among others. Each poses significant risks to nearby populations, with ongoing monitoring due to their potential for future eruptions
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'JD Vance is not authentic': Former White house press secretary Jen Psaki slams Republican US VP nominee saying 'voters are not dumb'
item.description: Jen Psaki criticized Republican VP nominee JD Vance for inauthenticity, noting his shift to support Donald Trump. Psaki emphasized Vance's inconsistency, stating voters are smart enough to notice. Recently, Vance's attempt to confront Kamala Harris further highlighted his campaign tactics. Trump announced Vance as his VP pick in July via Truth Social.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: US elections: Trump's 'Criminals for Kamala' video sparks controversy amid his own legal troubles
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Canadian man sues TikTok, Instagram, Facebook for ‘addictive’ design, citing harm to mental health
item.description: A 24-year-old Canadian man launched a lawsuit against TikTok, YouTube, Reddit, Instagram, and Facebook, claiming they create platforms that are too addictive. Represented by Lambert Avocats, he says social media has hurt his productivity and sleep since 2015. The lawsuit seeks compensatory and punitive damages, arguing the companies were negligent in their app design.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: ‘What am I doing?’: Biden appears confused at White House event honoring Texas Rangers; watch video
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Japan's scientists warn of a 'megaquake': What it means
item.description: Japan's earthquake scientists warned of a potential 'megaquake' in the future, which could cause massive loss of life. The Japan Meteorological Association issued this advisory under new guidelines post the 2011 disasters, cautioning about strong shaking and large tsunamis from the Nankai Trough, a significant subduction zone with past destructive quakes.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
